properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening. Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will end by Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-07T01:38:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T09:38:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0540047156.2021
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow today with 10 to 20 cm expected. A pacific storm system draped over the southern BC interior will bring heavy snow to Highway 3 - Kootenay Pass to Paulson Summit. Snow is forecast to ease this afternoon with light snow lingering into the early evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-07T02:44:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T10:44:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2254471988.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Wind gusts around 100 km/h are expected this morning. A wind gust of 103 km/h has been reported at Waterton Park Gate earlier this morning. The wind will weaken this afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of snow expected for the latter half of this week. Locations: the mid Labrador coast from Rigolet to Makkovik. Time span: beginning late in the day on Wednesday and lasting into the weekend. Remarks: Snow will develop in the Rigolet area Wednesday afternoon before spreading to Postville-Makkovik area Wednesday night. Snow is expected to persist through Thursday and likely Friday as well, with significant accumulations possible. At this time, it looks as if conditions will begin to improve for most areas by Saturday but accumulating snow is possible through the remainder of the weekend. Further details will be provided in subsequent messages, as it is too soon to accurately forecast amounts and duration of precipitation due to uncertainty. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-06T17:58:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T01:58:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3441607000.2021
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged freezing rain event is expected over higher terrain for Wednesday until Thursday morning. Locations: higher elevations from Norman Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: while coastal communities will quickly change over to rain Wednesday morning, freezing rain is forecast to continue through Wednesday for higher elevations of the Trans-Labrador Highway from Cartwright Junction to L'Anse-au-Clair. Travel is not recommended along the Trans-Labrador Highway until after the freezing rain has ended Thursday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-06T17:58:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T01:58:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4050030776.2021
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 45 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h. Locations: the mid Labrador coast from Rigolet to Makkovik. Time span: this evening until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop in the Rigolet area this afternoon before spreading to the Postville-Makkovik area this evening. The snow will persist through Thursday and Friday, with significant accumulations expected. The snow will combine with strengthening northerly winds to produce blowing snow, especially over exposed areas, on Thursday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-07T08:07:43-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged freezing rain event is expected over higher terrain today until Thursday morning. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: While most coastal communities will now only receive rain during this event, freezing rain is forecast to continue this afternoon and tonight for higher elevations of the Trans-Labrador Highway. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Utility outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Bitterly cold wind chill values in the -56 to -61 range are expected in Igloolik and Sanirajak this morning with temperatures in the -40's and northwest winds around 20 km/h. Increasing southerly winds overnight will usher in somewhat less frigid air for Thursday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-07T01:59:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T15:16:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1036450277.2021
Area: Sanirajak, Igloolik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 60 will continue until later this morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-06T20:29:55-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of mixed winter weather is expected for the latter half of this week. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Total rainfall through Friday night: 20 to 40 mm along the coast south of Black Tickle. Snow and ice pellets amounts: 15 to 25 cm today through Thursday in the Cartwright and Eagle River areas, with an additional 10 to 20 cm Thursday night to Friday night. Time span: continuing into the weekend. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets have changed over to rain along the coast south of Black Tickle. Freezing rain is expected for higher elevations of the Trans-Labrador Highway. For the Cartwright and Eagle River areas, precipitation will fall primarily as a mix of snow and ice pellets today and tonight. Freezing rain mixed with ice pellets is also expected this afternoon and evening. Conditions should improve slightly during the day on Thursday before another round of significant snowfall is anticipated for Thursday night into Friday. A break from the unsettled weather should begin by Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-07T08:08:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-06T16:09:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3856765117.2021
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Eagle River
